Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A New Molten-Oxide Electrochemical Process for Producing Primary Iron and Ferrochromium
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact / commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to advance the state of knowledge and industrial practice toward cleaner, cheaper, greener steel and stainless steel. The project will focus on the production of iron, part of a $1.1 trillion annual market worldwide, and ferrochromium, a $2.2 billion worldwide annual market. Molten oxide electrolysis with an inert anode has been demonstrated at the laboratory scale to produce low-carbon iron and ferroalloys, which are the basis of many high-performance steels. The current low-carbon metals sell at a premium. Published cost models show that both the capital and operating cost of MOE will be lower than competing technologies already in the marketplace. MOE can also reduce the environmental impact of producing these metals, even with today's electricity, and can produce even greater improvements with renewable energy. In summary, MOE will produce primary metals of higher quality at a lower cost and with lower environmental impact than current methods.

The objective of this Phase II research project is to develop a cheaper, more energy efficient route to production of important metals including iron and ferrochromium. Economical separation of these metals from their ores by molten oxide electrolysis (MOE) is enabled by the recent invention of an inert anode material. The essential next step in understanding the behavior of the new inert anode in MOE is longer-duration testing than was possible in the laboratory cell. This test can only be achieved at a larger scale. The models and testing on surrogate systems in Phase I have shown the way to provide this long-duration testing in Phase II. These tests will point the way toward industrial-scale production of iron and ferrochromium by MOE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The production of iron and ferro-chromium from ore by molten oxide electrolysis, using an inert anode, is scientifically interesting, and industrially unique.

The initial development of the inert anode material was pioneered in an academic lab. This material needed to be electrically conductive, solid, and non-reactive with oxygen at temperatures above the melting point of iron while immersed in a molten mixture of metal oxides. Bench scale experiments validated the material in the lab, and were repeated as part of this effort.

Industrially, a cost competitive process for the production of iron from a blast furnace without the use of carbon as a reductant is unavailable. Currently, iron reduced electrochemically is approximately five fold more expensive as iron reduced using carbon. Lowering the cost of carbon free iron production will disrupt the steel market, and remove carbon from both the upstream supply chain and emissions. Steel production represents approximately seven percent of anthropogenic carbon emissions. Production of iron using molten oxide electrolysis and an inert anode can reduce this to zero, when electricity comes from renewable resources.

Upscaling the anode material was the focus of this grant. The bench tests used an anode about the size of a thimble. Work performed under this award used an anode about the size of a watermelon. This increase in size required the use of a reaction vessel that was drastically different from the unit used to conduct bench level experiments. Bench scale experiments made use of an externally heated reactor while pilot scale experiments conducted under this grant used a reactor that was self-heating.

At the bench scale, oxygen was produced with minimal corrosion of the anode material. At the pilot scale experiments in the self-heated reactor were not able to demonstrate oxygen production at the anode, or the production of iron as measured by tracer dilution. Further work is necessary to elucidate the difference between bench and pilot scale results.
